so this talk was inspired by research that i learned about about a year and a half ago and it was
done by one of our research teams at adobe and they had spent several months visiting k-12 classrooms
across the united states learning about the technology the students were engaging with in the classroom at that time now
remember this is a year and a half ago so pre-pandemic time right the world is probably
different and it would be really interesting to do this research again but at that time
here's what the look the world looked like so they they talked to about 50 teachers administrators and students and
visited a mix of public and private schools and also looked at um some of the quantitative research that had been done
in this space really trying to understand what are the technology trends in schools and what i learned that day
when i was watching this report being presented is that in in schools at that time there were two
types of tools there were special project tools and core communication tools
as you might imagine special project tools are tools that are being used for projects things like making posters
with images videos telling a story interactive reports small books
and the tools that students use really varied a lot across teachers there was no one tool that each
each teacher encouraged their students to use in contrast core communication tools
were widely used across just about every teacher that the research team spoke with and some teachers mentioned that
they would actually scaffold use of these tools so they would introduce different parts of them over time and really you know wanted the
students to learn how to do this how to use these tools some of them
started teaching them as early as kindergarten and really these teachers felt the familiarity with with these
tools is an important part of computer literacy so as i sat there listening to this
report the question i asked myself was um what are the core communication
tools of the future right so for today you can based on the icons you can guess these core communication tools are things like

are there any of adobe's tools that ever will ever be core communication tools that will be

so one axis of this framework is are you trying to create video are you consuming video so what are you
doing with video another one is is this an interactive task or a passive task right so
sitting down and watching tv or watching a movie that's a passive task actually trying to like pick browse a
video and quickly find some information that's interactive another axis is this
an iterative task or a one-time task right so um
do you do this over and over with the same video or just one time
individual or collaborative are you doing this with others or by yourself and then if you are doing
it with others is the synchronous or asynchronous so let's go through some examples of of
how to apply the framework so you are all attending this talk for you this is the consumption task
for some of you it's totally passive you're just listening for others it is interactive maybe
you're jotting things down maybe you're even you know interacting with me with the questions
it is a one-time experience i don't think i'll come back and do it again
um it is collaborative we're doing this together you're doing this with others and it is very much synchronous
now let's say you're actually watching a recording of this talk for you this would be again a

when we're watching videos you may come back to this over and over again maybe you watch it once

um right there's a rising trend in online videos for vlogging of course i'm guessing you guys know this this is
a multi-billion dollar business on youtube with millions of subscribers and these videos are often a vlogger so
like this guy talking about some kind of topic and so it's often like a headshot of him or her but there's cutaways
to some kind of effect and this type of cutaway is what we call b-roll and so the b-script system um
assists users with this last part to find and insert b-roll that goes into making this video about
this specific topic and so this is what the b-script interface looks like it has a video
preview and a timeline transcript view which supports navigation by clicking and a search panel for actual b-roll
footage which is integrated with the interface so users can double-click on a word in the transcript and then
search for relevant b-roll footage now the core of the interface is
actually a recommendation system so it analyzes the transcripts text and makes recommendations for good locations
for where to insert the b-roll and what the content of that b-roll should be so here the green light
the green highlights indicate the recommended b-roll location and then the keywords on the right show
the actual query you could use to find relevant content and so all you have to do as a user is
click on that query and then you see a list of potential b-roll that you can add to your video
so i one thing before i show you the results note that there is no like timeline
there is no in and out points you're really just using the transcript as a way to decide where to add
additional footage and of course you know this is one specific interface it's not going to be general purpose for everything but it is an example of what
we can do if we really narrow down our use case and so here are some examples on the
left and on the right of kind of two of the same video one with b-roll and one without

um all right so let's talk about restream so this was work
um done at a derby at the time ailee frazier who is now at adobe she was a
phd student at ucsd and this is really
um looking at creative live streams so um so far so i just kind of shifting
gears a little bit in b script we talked a lot about creation right we're creating videos this is really all about consumption so
for the past several years um we've been studying creative live streaming and there's a growing interest in general and creative live streaming
at adobe because there is a growing community of artists who are streaming live this was true even before
the pandemic but of course with the pandemic it's really kind of increased significantly
and so here is an example of such a stream and in general artists are now broadcasting as they work on
these creative projects and they do this with multiple goals in mind some are teaching and trying to
share their practice some are just working actually without talking very much
and then others use this um platform to socialize with other artists so note that artists are often freelancers
and they may be at home working by themselves and so getting connected to others um through a stream is a way to build a
community and what's interesting about live streams is that they unlike tutorials
um show an unedited process behind the creative work so it's not really a step-by-step
tutorial you see everything you see the mistakes the decisions
anything that happens along the way and so we often think about live streams as something that people consume live
but many of these platforms also archive these videos and then people can come back to them
and watch them which is nice because of course not all of us can be there
at the same time as each other and especially when you have a you know artists from all over the world
streaming in their own time zones it's not possible for uh each of us to catch up with the artists we love so
and while these videos are pretty amazing and they have this like wealth of knowledge it's pretty
challenging to browse them right you can imagine many of these are three four hours long
and it's just really hard to make sense of which parts to watch
and so in this work we really focused on this idea of how do we take these creative live stream archives
you know these are videos that are quite long how do we make it easier to watch and navigate them
one way to do that is with a table of contents that divides um the content into sections and
many people do manually make these as i said youtube now um supports actually parsing of these
descriptions and then many websites like this is skillshare actually um add that as part of the authoring
interface as part of the video sharing interface directly and so as part of this work we spoke
with streamers and viewers about the value of having such a table of contents and find found that for streamers um they do see
a value in having this table of contents but they don't have the time to make it so they've sat down they've just
streamed for multiple hours the last thing they want to do is actually do anything for that content
and for viewers it was really useful to see a table of contents as an overview and
get a quick understanding of what happened however we also found that viewers of
the same video really differed in what they wanted from a table of contents and that there was
no right way for us to segment creative live streams so some were really interested in
specific techniques others really wanted to know kind of the overall experience
and so it the other part of this is that these streams don't often have as obvious of a structure as tutorials
and so it makes it harder to figure out what table of contents to create but on the other hand since
there are many different possible segmentations many different possible table of contents perhaps
any table of content is better table of contents is better than nothing and so um to do this we put together an
approach and it's a user in the loop approach so the system first automatically segments the live
stream into sections and then the streamer uses this automatic segmentation and adds titles
and adjusts any sections so sometimes there might be two um smaller sections
that really should be one and so the streamer can put them together and this allows the streamer to really maintain agency over their content
how does this work um we have a segmentation algorithm that takes um that can take advantage of well in
general the way you would want to do this is you would want to look at both what's happening visually you would want to look at what the audio
is like what is the streamer saying uh what's happening in the software you know if you have access to that or
you're able to extract that from the video what is what are the tools someone's using and then of course you have the
chat so you can take all this information and try to create a table of contents in this
particular work um we used only the narration and the software actions in subsequent work we've looked at how
to take advantage of the visual information as well and so the algorithm essentially identifies
candidate boundaries based on the software actions and the narration
identifies intro and outro because they look quite different than the middles and then combines the remaining
intervals into sections and to determine what these
sections should be we use um a scoring function that combines four
heuristics uh one of them is around duration we prioritized in this
particular project that sections should be between 1 and 10 minutes long based on our conversations with
streamers we also based on prior works found that um
certain commands indicate the start and end of a subtask
also we found that certain um tasks the they use streamers use the same tools in
certain tasks so they group certain tools um as they're working on a specific task
and then last we looked at the transcript semantics and looked for words like start and next and done and that's all because
those often also indicate transitions
so to evaluate the algorithm's output with streamers we built a prototype interface and had
them actually use it and evaluate both the um the sections that this
algorithm created and then also labeled them
and so this is an example of what it looks like after someone has labeled it
and we also had the fortune of being able to work with the behance team which is adobe's creative social network and a
version of this algorithm is actually deployed now on the website and so if you go to the behance website
you'll see that some of the live streams have chapters uh where that are segmented
and give an overview
and so some of the takeaways from restream are that streamers really like the automatically created sections
and the algorithm definitely performed better on some streams than others instructional streams where there is a
linear structure and you go from one section to the next to the next are much easier to segment in a
meaningful way than um streams where there's a lot of back and forth and the streamer isn't
quite sure what process they're going to follow so that type of exploration is harder to discover
with the current approach that we've been uh trying and so that's definitely an interesting space for future work
and so if we look at the um how restream fits into the framework it is definitely a consumption interface
it is interactive it's something they can use over and over or just one time you know it depends on your consumption
and then again it's something that you use on your own all right so we have one last poll
